Real-World Evidence-Based Herbal Medicine for Aging GMP Herbal Formulations for Age-Related Traits from Deep Learning Medical Claims Data Overview

Real-World Evidence-Based Herbal Medicine for Aging GMP Herbal Formulations for Age-Related Traits from Deep Learning Medical Claims Data Sun-Chong Wang 2025-09-29 Overview Responding to the global demographic shift towards an aging population, this book presents clinically derived herbal prescriptions—available as dietary supplements—designed to relieve age-related health conditions and extend healthspan. Unlike conventional drug development’s one-size-fits-all approach, this book addresses the complexities of multimorbidity common in older adults. Derived from a decade’s worth of Taiwanese medical claims data—encompassing approximately 5,000 herbal medical doctors’ expertise—the book focuses on herbal treatments actually used in clinical practice. Organized around identified hallmarks of aging, it associates these phenotypes with prescriptions through a state-of-the-art generative artificial intelligence model, ensuring broad applicability. Each section details related signs/symptoms alongside corresponding GMP granulated herbal prescriptions. The use of the components in the prescriptions is further supported by modern preclinical, clinical studies and, where available, their meta-analyses. This resource is ideal for geriatric practitioners, researchers, and anyone seeking safe, low-cost, and complementary approaches to healthy aging. No prior knowledge of traditional medicine or machine learning is required.

Preface According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the global population aged 60 years and older is projected to double from 2020 to 2050, reaching 2.1 billion, while those aged 80 and above will triple to 0.4 billion.1 By 2050, these age groups will account for 22% and 4% of the world population, respectively. This demographic shift is driven by increased life expectancy and declining birth rates, leading to an overall rise in median age and accelerated population aging. While people are living longer, their healthspan—the period during which they remain healthy—has not significantly increased, resulting in older individuals spending their additional years in poor health. This aging population presents a particularly challenging issue for developing countries in Asia and Africa, which often lack the resources to effectively address these demographic changes. A key epidemiological characteristic of geriatrics is multimorbidity,2 where elderly patients typically suffer from multiple concurrent diseases. The traditional paradigm of drug development in modern Western medicine (MWM) focuses on a one drug-one target/disease approach, which may not be well-suited for older patients with complex health needs. As a result, reviewing polypharmacy-related adverse effects has become a routine part of geriatric assessments within MWM. Since aging is influenced by a combination of genetics, behavior, and environmental factors, the varied aging trajectories highlight the need for patient-tailored medicine for the elderly. Historically, ancient healers relied on natural products, particularly plant roots and rhizomes, to alleviate various conditions such as pain, fatigue, and insomnia, despite lacking an understanding of genetics and cellular biology. Over time, these natural remedies were combined into decoctions designed to address multiple conditions across different organ systems, such as the lungs and skin. Today, many traditional decoctions have been refined into concentrated granules by Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP)-certified manufacturers,3 akin to the processing of fresh milk into instant milk powder. This book presents prescriptions utilizing these granulated herbal products, available as dietary supplements in the U.S., aimed at relieving the health conditions of the elderly and extending their healthspan. Approach and Features Aging is a complex process, but since 2013 researchers have illuminated various hallmarks of aging—aging mechanisms that operate at the molecular, cellular, and systemic levels.4 Aging phenotypes associated with each hallmark have been identified through the co-occurrence of these phenotypes and hallmarks in research articles indexed in the PubMed database of the National Library of Medicine, National Institutes of Health, U.S.5 We then associate these aging phenotypes with herbal prescriptions using a state-of-the-art AI model trained on a decade’s worth of medical claims data from Taiwan,6 whose medical insurance program has reimbursed GMP-certified granular herbal prescriptions since its establishment in 1995. Importantly, the herbal prescriptions featured in this book are derived from real-world usage data provided by licensed traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) physicians, rather than from texts written by ancient healers. Our Transformer-based AI model shares similarities with ChatGPT but differs in that its data inputs and expected outputs are clearly defined. This structured approach prevents the AI model from generating inaccuracies or “hallucinations.” The model’s generalization capability allows it to recommend treatments for a wide range of disease combinations. Because it is built on the collective insights of approximately 5,000 TCM physicians who contributed to the medical claims data, the prescriptions in this book represent a broad spectrum of expertise, rather than specialized focus of individual practitioners as seen in most other sources. Organization of the book The book explores 86 common traits associated with human aging, organized into distinct sections. Each section begins with an introduction to the trait, followed by a table that lists comorbid signs or diseases alongside their corresponding GMP herbal prescriptions. At the end of each section, the author provides annotations for the herbs mentioned in the table, citing the latest peer-reviewed pharmacologic studies—both clinical and preclinical—related to the constituent herbs and formulas. Chapter 1 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Genomic Instability and Telomere Attrition A genome encompasses all DNA sequences—both nuclear and mitochondrial—that encode the instructions necessary for an organism’s development, function, and survival. The integrity of the genome can be compromised by endogenous factors such as DNA replication/repair errors, telomere attrition, spontaneous mutations, and reactive oxygen species (ROS), as well as exogenous agents like ionizing radiation, ultraviolet (UV) light, and environmental mutagens (e.g., acetaldehyde, aflatoxins, arsenic, asbestos, benzene, formaldehyde, oncoviruses, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and tobacco-specific nitrosamines). These insults can lead to genomic instability. While changes in DNA sequences introduce genetic diversity, which enhances the adaptive capacity of microorganisms to environmental challenges, genome conservation is critical for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of multicellular organisms. Throughout evolution, a delicate balance between genomic diversity and conservation has been fine-tuned to ensure survival across the tree of life. However, evidence suggests that this equilibrium is disrupted in aging cells. For instance, DNA base excision repair efficiency declines in human cells with age (Atamna et al., 2000), and telomeres in adult leukocytes shorten by approximately 25 base pairs annually (Müezzinler et al., 2013). The concept of “aging hallmarks”—a set of biological processes central to human aging—was first proposed by López-Otín et al. (2013) and later expanded upon in subsequent studies (López-Otín, Blasco, et al., 2023). These hallmarks include critical processes such as genome instability and telomere attrition. Building on this framework, Andreassen et al. (2019) identified signs and symptoms associated with these aging hallmarks. Concurrently, S.-C. Wang (2023) systematically elucidated the clinical application of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP)-certified herbal prescriptions for addressing signs, symptoms, and diseases. Based on these findings, it is now possible to develop targeted GMP herbal prescriptions tailored to specific aging phenotypes associated with individual hallmarks. The GMP herbs and formulations included in the prescriptions discussed in this chapter are as follows: Guīpítāng, Fúshén, Yèjiāoténg, Suānzǎoréntāng, Dānshēn, Tiānwángbǔxīndān, Xuèfǔzhúyūtāng, Bǔzhōngyìqìtāng, Tǔfúlíng, Héshǒuwū, Hànliáncǎo, Nǔzhēnzǐ, Yuǎnzhì, Qībǎoměirándān, Rénshēnyǎngróngtāng, Xiāngshāliùjūnzǐtāng, and Sǎnzhǒngkuìjiāntāng. 1.1 Graying of hair Gray hair is one of the most visible and also earliest signs of aging in humans. Hair color is determined by melanin pigments produced by the melanocytes in hair follicles. Defects in the synthesis of melanin, due, e.g., to oxidative stress-induced melanocyte apoptosis or senescence, drive graying of hair. Cumulative intrafollicular free radicals also disrupt maintenance of melanocyte stem cells residing in the bulge of hair follicles and depletion of the melanocyte stem cells perpetuates hair graying (O’Sullivan et al., 2020). Although the onset age of hair graying varies from person to person, non-genetic risk factors such as hormone imbalance, psychoemotional stress, nutrient deficiencies, UV radiation, tobacco smoking, and medication have been implicated to play a role in graying initiation. A systematic review and meta-analysis found that people with premature graying of hair are likely to be obese or hypertensive (Mahendiratta et al., 2020). Both collagen and elastin are synthesized and secreted by the fibroblasts in the dermis. Accumulated DNA damage to the fibroblasts due to endogenous and UV-induced ROS can cause fibroblast senescence, exacerbating dermal aging. In vivo quantification of oxidative stress in human facial skin was developed and oxidative stress was shown to correlate with age and wrinkle score in areas surrounding the eye (Tsuchida & Kobayashi, 2020). Looking younger was found to be associated with less chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and osteoporosis (Mekić et al., 2023). Hsu et al., 2005). 1.3 Telangiectasia Telangiectasias, also known as spider veins, refer to prominent, dilated small blood vessels (arterioles, venules, or capillaries) near the surface of the skin, often on the face or legs. Arteriolar (venular) telangiectasias are red (blue) in color. The dilated vessels are small in diameter (< 1mm) and thus do not protrude above the skin surface. Capillary telangiectasias are initially small and red but can become wide and blue with time. Telangiectasias are generally asymptomatic and represent primarily as a cosmetic concern. The etiology of telangiectasias is not clear. However, as the risk factors of telangiectasias include sunlight exposure, age, temperature extremes, and hormonal fluctuations, weakness of the blood vessel walls due to age-related DNA damage may play a role in chronic venous insufficiency such as telangiectasis (Ortega et al., 2021). The comorbidities of chronic venous disease include emphysema and diabetes (Matic et al., 2015). Anemia in the elderly was associated with cardiovascular diseases and cognitive impairments (Stauder & Thein, 2014). Lymphocytes consist of helper T-cells, cytotoxic T-cells, B-cells, and natural killer (NK) cells; the former three are involved in the cell-mediated, cytotoxic, and humoral adaptive immunity respectively, and the last are part of cell-mediated, cytotoxic innate immunity. The total lymphocytes were found to decline progressively from infancy, adolescence, adulthood to old age although the number of NK cells increased in the elderly (Valiathan et al., 2016). Fewer lymphocytes compromise immunity. Shorter leukocyte telomere length was indeed found to be associated with a higher risk of infection and pneumonia (Helby et al., 2017). The total cerebellar volume was found to shrink after 50 years of age (Luft et al., 1999) and the age-related cerebellar shrinking depends on cerebellar regions and sex (Y. Wang, Teng, et al., 2024). A dramatic increase in non-random DNA double-strand breaks and aneuploidy was found in the cerebellum of patients with ataxia telangiectasia, which is a rare genetic disorder featuring cerebellar atrophy. Because the cerebellum, an integral part of the brain functional network, connects to the cerebral cortex and limbic system, cerebellar dysfunction also causes a constellation of cognitive and affective deficits including executive function impairment, spatial recognition difficulties, language deficits, and personality changes (Schmahmann & Sherman, 1998). Region-specific cerebellar atrophy is seen in early stages of dementia subtypes including Alzheimer’s disease, diffuse neocortical Lewy body disease, and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (Y. Chen et al., 2023). He, Zhao, et al., 2020). Suānzǎoréntāng contains Suānzǎorén as the major herb. Yuǎnzhì (Radix Polygalae) was reviewed to have neuroprotective effects for CNS disorders including psychosis and neurodegeneration (N. Jiang et al., 2021). Tiānwángbǔxīndān, comprising Tiānméndōng, Suānzǎorén, and Yuǎnzhì, was suggested to be effective in the treatment of insomnia in a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (X. Yang et al., 2019). Yèjiāoténg (Caulis Polygoni Multiflori) was shown to relieve sleep disturbances in insomnia mice via mechanisms including antioxidant pathway (R. Zhong et al., 2024) and Fúshén (Poria cum Radix Pini) was demonstrated to enhance sleep behaviors in mice through GABAA-ergic mechanisms (Shah et al., 2014). Dàzǎo is anticancer (Tahergorabi et al., 2015) and Gégēn is analgesic (rf. Section 1.3). 1.8 Cancer Cancerous cells not only proliferate rapidly and indefinitely but also spread through bloodstream or lymphatic system to other parts of the body such as the bones, liver, and lungs. Crushing or blocking of the invaded and metastasized cells on the nearby and distal parts of the originating site cause cancer morbidity and mortality. Cancer is the leading cause of death; it was estimated that approximately one in five people develop cancer in a lifetime, whereas around one in nine men and one in 12 women die from it (Bray et al., 2024). Damage of DNA, especially in the tumor suppressor genes, initiates carcinogenesis; therefore, genome instability is called enabling hallmark of cancer (Hanahan & Weinberg, 2000). However, telomere attrition and stem cell exhaustion suppress oncogenesis. The agonistic and antagonistic relationship between aging hallmarks and cancer hallmarks may explain the observed age-related increase and oldest age-related decrease in cancer morbidity and mortality (López-Otín, Pietrocola, et al., 2023). Chapter 2 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Epigenetic Alterations Genes are dynamically read and utilized by cells throughout the cell cycle and in response to external stimuli. However, the accessibility and transcription of genes in the nucleus can be hindered by various factors, such as nutrient imbalances (e.g., deficiencies in folate and B vitamins), lifestyle factors (e.g., smoking, alcohol consumption, and physical inactivity), psychological stress, exposure to environmental chemicals (e.g., bisphenol A and heavy metals), and atmospheric pollutants (e.g., particulate matter). These effects are mediated by epigenetic mechanisms, including DNA methylation, histone modifications, and overproduction of miRNAs, without altering the underlying DNA sequences. Epigenetic research over the past decades has confirmed that accumulated epigenetic changes are closely associated with aging. Consequently, pronounced epigenetic alterations serve as early indicators of the onset of aging and age-related diseases (Dhar et al., 2022). This chapter presents traditional herbal prescriptions from the GMP (Good Manufacturing Practice) system that are used to address aging traits associated with epigenetic alterations. A key characteristic of aging individuals is the simultaneous presence of multiple medical conditions. Therefore, we present herbal prescriptions targeting both the aging traits and their related comorbidities. Commonly prescribed herbs and formulas for these conditions include: Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn, Hànliáncǎo, Nǔzhēnzǐ, Qǐjúdìhuángwán, Cháihújiālónggǔmǔlìtāng, Héhuānpí, Fúlíng, Gāncǎoxiǎomàidàzǎotāng, Dānshēn, Lǐzhōngtāng, Bǔzhōngyìqìtāng, Fángfēng, Zhǐqiào, Jiégěng, Gānjiāng, Suānzǎorén, and Guìzhītāng. 2.1 Psychiatric symptom A major psychiatric symptom in geriatrics is delirium, which is characterized by episodes of mental dysfunction including disturbances in attention, awareness, and global cognition such as memory, orientation, language, and perception. An episode of delirium occurs abruptly and can last for hours to days. The risk factors of delirium in adult patients include advanced age, surgery, and infection (Ormseth et al., 2023), all of which involve inflammation. Indeed, the DNA methylation levels at the pro-inflammatory cytokine genes in the microglia and blood samples of neurosurgical and traumatic patients were found to decrease with age; the age-related DNA methylation changes in the cytokine genes in glia and blood were thus hypothesized to contribute to the pathophysiology of delirium (Shinozaki et al., 2018), which is frequently comorbid with dementia, diabetes, and hypertension (Z. Lim et al., 2023). Chen et al., 2020). 2.2 Anxiety Anxiety, a feeling of uneasiness and worry, is the emotional responses to an anticipated, uncontrollable, future threat. It is closely related to fear, which is the fight-or-flight response to a real, recognized, current threat. Examples of anxiety include the nervous emotions and behaviors of students before taking an exam, unsocial persons before meeting a stranger, and elderly patients before reading a diagnosis. If the anxiety state persists and becomes disabling even after the stressor is removed, the state turns into an anxiety disorder. It is well known that early environmental insult, such as childhood abuse, has a lingering effect on one’s entire life. Epigenetic deregulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, which triggers fight-or-flight response, in anxious animals and humans has been intensely studied and summarized (Bartlett et al., 2017; Persaud & Cates, 2022). Generalized anxiety disorder is associated with depression and chronic pain (Rogers et al., 2020). Li et al., 2015) and migraine (Y. Wang, Shi, et al., 2019). 2.3 Anosmia Anosmia is loss of the sense of all or some smells. In humans, the olfactory sensory neurons (OSNs) in the lining of the nasal cavity detect airborne and foodborne odors and then transduce electric signals to the olfactory bulb in the roof of the nasal cavity, where the olfactory signals are relayed to other parts of the forebrain, including hypothalamus and amygdala, for further processing. Although epidemiological studies consistently find increasing prevalence of anosmia and dysgeusia with age, the mechanisms remain obscure (Doty & Kamath, 2014). Nevertheless, a recent study demonstrated the downregulation of olfactory receptor (OR) genes through altered chromatin organization of the OSNs upon SARS-CoV-2 infection, and the disruptions in the OR transcription and compartmentalization remain long after viral clearance (Zazhytska et al., 2022). In addition, aging-related inflammatory changes in olfactory stem cells in nasal olfactory mucosa were shown to contribute to presbyosmia in humans (Oliva et al., 2022). Olfactory dysfunction is common in patients with Alzheimer’s disease or Parkinson’s disease (Papazian & Pinto, 2021). Childhood trauma, such as neglect and emotional abuse, was found to increase the risk of adult-onset depression (Mandelli et al., 2015). The prevalence of depression in adults was estimated at 13% (G. Y. Lim et al., 2018), while that in old people increased to 32% (Zenebe et al., 2021). Adaptive and maladaptive responses to stressful events in lifespan accumulate and can gradually disrupt the interconnectivity of the functional brain network, causing depression in later life. Epigenetics is a mechanism mediating lasting effects of the environment. DNA hypermethylation at BDNF (a nerve growth factor) and SLC6A4 (serotonin reuptake transporter) was consistently found to be associated with depression (M. Li et al., 2019). Hypertension, diabetes, and cataract were the most common physical comorbidities in old patients with depression (Grover et al., 2017). An increasing concentration of THs in the blood inhibits pituitary production of TSH. Levels of TSH and THs are maintained in a negative feedback loop so that high levels of TSH signify low levels of THs. A longitudinal study found that environmental chemicals (i.e., organophosphate esters (OPEs) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)) in the blood and urine of the elderly are associated with accelerated epigenetic aging and that high TSH and low THs aggravate the contaminant-induced epigenetic aging (W. Shi et al., 2024). OPEs were shown to migrate from plastic food packaging to food (Bi et al., 2023). PAHs, produced by incomplete combustion of biomass, are ubiquitous in engine exhaust, incinerator emissions, and cigarette smoke. The common comorbidities of thyroid dysfunction include diabetes and hypertension (Rashad & Samir, 2019). Section 2.6) was shown to improve the adrenal function and short-term survival of septic rats (F. Lai et al., 2018). An in silico study elucidated the effect of Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn (rf. Section 2.4) on cholesterol metabolism and ovarian steroidogenesis in the treatment of polycystic ovary syndrome (Leclerc et al., 2020). A glycoprotein extracted from Tiānhuā (Radix Trichosanthis) was also shown to inhibit tumor growth in a Lewis lung carcinoma mouse model via DNA methyltransferase DNMT3B mediated mitochondrial calcium influx and tumor cell death (Y. Zhang et al., 2025). Trichosanthis seeds were also shown to inhibit the growth of two human colorectal cancer cell lines (S. M. Park et al., 2019). Note that Sǎnzhǒngkuìjiāntāng (rf. Section 1.8) contains Tiānhuā. Shíliùwèiliúqìyǐn was shown to suppress the growth of human bladder carcinoma cells-xenografted tumor tissues in mice (Ou et al., 2011). Sections 1.3 and 2.2) was shown to reduce the growth of human colorectal cancer cells in a dose-dependent manner through induction of apoptosis (Z. Yu & Li, 2006). Chapter 3 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Loss of Proteostasis and Disabled Macroautophagy The life cycle of proteins begins with the folding of amino acid sequences into functional three-dimensional structures. These proteins are then transported to specific intracellular or extracellular compartments where they perform their biological roles. When misfolded, aggregated, or no longer required, they are degraded by cellular quality control systems. As the workhorses of the cell, maintaining protein homeostasis (proteostasis) relies on a complex network of molecular machineries, including molecular chaperones, the proteasome, and (macro)autophagy pathways. However, proteostasis can be overwhelmed by factors such as spontaneous genetic mutations, oxidative stress, and persistent environmental insults—including exposure to extreme temperatures, cold stress, dehydration, ultraviolet radiation, heavy metals, alcohol, pH fluctuations, and infections. Over time, the accumulation of misfolded and damaged proteins leads to cellular dysfunction and age-related pathologies, such as neurodegenerative diseases (Labbadia & Morimoto, 2015). In traditional Chinese medicine, GMP-certified herbs and formulas are frequently employed to address medical conditions linked to impaired protein quality control systems. These include: Yuǎnzhì, Dānshēn, Zīshènmíngmùtāng, Qǐjúdìhuángwán, Shíchāngpú, Juémíngzǐ, Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn, Bǔyánghuánwǔtāng, Tùsīzǐ, Ròucōngróng, Sháoyàogāncǎotāng, Yìqìcōngmíngtāng, Chēqiánzǐ, Nǔzhēnzǐ, Gǔjīngcǎo, and Zhìgāncǎotāng. 3.1 Cataract A cataract is an opaque region in the eye lens. The eye lens is composed predominantly of crystallin proteins, which help maintain proper refractivity and transparency of the lens. The protein structure of alpha-crystallin, one of the three crystallin subtypes in vertebrates, is similar to that of small heat-shock proteins; alpha-crystallin has thus chaperone-like properties, preventing precipitation of misfolded proteins and formation of large light-scattering aggregates in cataractous lens. Lens proteins including alpha-crystallin, albeit long-lived, denature and degrade over time. Defective alpha-crystallin was shown to alter lens morphology, autophagy, and stress responses, leading to lens opacification in aged mice with alpha-crystallin mutant knock-in (Andley & Goldman, 2016). The common systemic comorbidities in patients undergoing cataract surgery were identified to be hypertension and diabetes (Mishrikotkar et al., 2021). Presbyopia, also known as age-related farsightedness, is the inability to focus clearly on close objects because of increased stiffness of the eye lens. It was shown that presbyopia results from a loss of alpha-crystallin in the center of the lens together with progressive heat-induced denaturation of structural proteins in the lens (Heys et al., 2007). Another common age-related visual acuity impairment is myodesopsias or vitreous floaters. The vitreous is the transparent gel-like fluid that fills the space between the lens and the retina of the eyeball. Molecular alterations in the vitreous such as aggregation of collagen fibrils can form fibers that scatter light and cast tiny shadows called floaters on the retina. Musculoskeletal conditions or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbate the decline in health-related quality-of-life in visually impaired old patients (Van Nispen et al., 2009). Sound vibrations cause bending or deflection of the cilia of the hair cells in the cochlea. The function of the hair cells is to amplify and convert the acoustic stimuli into electrochemical signals, which are relayed via the auditory nerve to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the brain for further analysis. Damages, e.g., noise and ototoxicity, to the auditory cells, tissues, and their microenvironments accumulate over time and contribute to presbycusis. It was shown in old rats that upregulation of autophagy inhibits apoptosis to promote survival of inner ear hair cells (Z. He et al., 2021) and to slow degeneration of auditory cortex neurons (J. Yuan et al., 2018). Presbycusis is linked to depression and dementia (Bowl & Dawson, 2019). The most common symptoms of AD are loss of short-term memory and difficulty in finding words, first appearing around 65 years of age. AD is believed to be caused by aggregates of intracellular hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (called tau tangles) and extracellular misfolded beta-amyloid (called amyloid plaques) in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex responsible for memory, language, reasoning, and social behaviors. The global prevalence of the AD continuum, including prodromal AD, preclinical AD, and AD, was estimated at 22% of all persons aged 50 and above (Gustavsson et al., 2022). PD is caused by aggregates of misfolded alpha-synuclein proteins in the cytoplasm of the dopamine-releasing neurons in the region of the midbrain involved in reward and movement. Aberrant alpha-synuclein can transmit to damage neighboring cells, contributing to disease propagation. Advanced stages of PD manifest nonmotor symptoms such as depression, constipation, and sleep disorders. PD affects 1% of the population above 60 years old (Tysnes & Storstein, 2017). An episode of seizure can last for seconds to minutes. A seizure can be provoked by high fever, central nervous system infection, head trauma, electrocyte imbalance, medication use/withdrawal, and so on. Repeated unprovoked seizures are called epilepsy. The age distribution of epilepsy prevalence shows bimodal peaks at the two ends: pediatric patients and geriatric patients (Beghi & Giussani, 2018). Among the elders, most seizures are secondary to epileptogenic conditions such as stroke and dementia, while new-onset seizures are due to alcohol withdrawal, strokes, and electrolyte disturbances (Zagaria, 2008). The prevalence of AF increases with increasing age (Lakshminarayan et al., 2006). Structural remodeling of the atrial cardiomyocytes resulting from proteostasis derailment, including exhaustion of heat shock proteins, disruption of cytoskeletal proteins, and DNA damage-induced NAD+ depletion, was reviewed to promote AF (N. Li & Brundel, 2020). Obesity, alcohol consumption, and cigarette smoking predispose AF; and hypertension, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and chronic renal dysfunction are among the common comorbidities of AF (Naser et al., 2017). Bājǐtiān (Radix Morindae Officinalis), Ròucōngróng (Herba Cistanches), Yínyánghuò (Herba Epimedii), Tùsīzǐ (Semen Cuscutae), Gǒuqǐzǐ (rf. Section 3.1), and Dāngguī (rf. Section 2.3) are all aphrodisiac, improving the erectile function of rodents (H. Li et al., 2017). In addition, Bājǐtiān was shown to promote the proliferation of osteoblasts, enhance their viability, and maintain the balance between bone resorption and formation in rats with osteoporosis (Qiao et al., 2022); Ròucōngróng was shown to reverse bone loss and prevent osteoporosis in ovariectomized rats (H. Liang et al., 2011); Yínyánghuò was shown to promote the osteogenic differentiation of human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (J. Zhang et al., 2010); and Tùsīzǐ was shown to inhibit bone resorption by osteoclasts in ovariectomized mice (Y. Yang, Wei, et al., 2022). Furthermore, the antiosteoporosis effect of Bājǐtiān, Ròucōngróng, and Yínyánghuò through autophagy was reviewed (Y. Zhou et al., 2023). Both Yòuguīwán (rf. Section 2.5) and Zuǒguīwán contain Shúdìhuáng (rf. Section 3.4), Shānyào (rf. Section 3.1), Gǒuqǐzǐ (rf. Section 3.1), and Tùsīzǐ; Zuǒguīwán was shown to enhance the bone mineral density in ovariectomized mice as well as in naturally aged mice by regulating the Th17/Treg paradigm (N. Lai et al., 2015). A compound derived from Báizhú (rf. Section 3.2) was shown to inhibit human prostate cancer cell line proliferation through induction of cell cycle arrest (J. Wang, Nasser, et al., 2018). Běishāshēn (rf. Section 1.2) was shown to be cardiovascular protective in high-fat-diet-fed obese mice through hypolipidemic effects (H.-J. Lim et al., 2016). Chapter 4 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Mitochondrial Dysfunction Mitochondria are cellular organelles responsible for converting nutrients from food into ATP, the energy currency that powers essential cellular processes such as intra- and extracellular signaling, RNA/DNA/protein synthesis, substrate transport, neurotransmission, and muscle contraction. When mitochondria malfunction, they not only impair ATP production but also elevate the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can compromise organ function (e.g., brain, heart, and muscle) and damage critical cellular components (e.g., DNA, lipids, and proteins). Numerous environmental agents—including heavy metals like cadmium, lead, mercury, and arsenic; chemical pollutants such as pesticides, herbicides, bisphenols, and phthalates; and substances like alcohol, antibiotics, and statins—exhibit mitochondrial toxicity (Pizzorno, 2022). Many of the GMP-prescribed herbal formulations for addressing aging-related signs and symptoms discussed in this chapter include the following components: Dānshēn, Jìshēngshènqìwán, Zhìgāncǎotāng, Shēngmàiyǐn, Bǔyánghuánwǔtāng, Yuǎnzhì, Sìnìtāng, Niúxī, Shūjīnghuóxuètāng, Shíchāngpú, Chēqiánzǐ, Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn, Bǔzhōngyìqìtāng, and Zhūlíngtāng. In addition to these herbal regimens, acupuncture is frequently prescribed as a complementary therapy for the health conditions described in this chapter. Research has demonstrated acupuncture’s potential to improve mitochondrial function in various contexts: for instance, it has been shown to reverse hippocampal mitochondrial dysfunction in vascular dementia rats (H. Li et al., 2016), promote cerebral mitochondrial biogenesis and neural recovery in ischemic stroke rats (K. Guo & Lu, 2024), and support muscular mitochondrial function in rats following acute swimming exercise (M. Gao et al., 2008). These findings highlight the growing recognition of acupuncture as a valuable adjunct to GMP herbal therapies in addressing age-related health challenges. 4.1 Cerebral atrophy The volume of brain tissue in healthy individuals decreases at a rate of 0.5% per year after age 40. In the normal aging brain, the loss of gray matter tissue is region specific while the loss of white matter is widespread (Resnick et al., 2003). After 70 years of age when 14% of the brain volume has lost, the rate of brain atrophy accelerates. This increasing rate may parallel an underlying neurodegenerative disease such as Alzheimer’s disease. A common CNS manifestation of mitochondrial diseases is atrophy (Finsterer & De Carvalho, 2017). For example, a study found that mitochondrial genome variations predict whole brain and regional brain atrophy in patients with Alzheimer’s disease (Ridge et al., 2013). Besides advanced age, transient ischemic attacks, hypertension, smoking, hyperlipidemia, and excessive alcohol consumption were found to accelerate cerebral atrophy in normal aging adults (Akiyama et al., 1997). Nevertheless, cerebral blood flow was found to decrease at a rate of about 0.5% per year with increasing age; the decrease was mainly attributed to decreasing gray matter perfusion in the prefrontal cortex (Parkes et al., 2004). The decreasing cerebral blood flow is consistent with the finding of lower neuronal mitochondrial metabolism and glutamate–glutamine cycle flux in the brain of elderly adults compared with young adults (Boumezbeur et al., 2009). Furthermore, the age-related hypoperfused regions differ from the age-related atrophic regions (J. J. Chen et al., 2011), indicating that the effect of age on the brain is manifold. For example, insulin resistance and elevated BMI were found to be associated with lower regional cerebral flood flow in cognitively asymptomatic and healthy adults, respectively (Hoscheidt et al., 2017; Willeumier et al., 2011). Individuals with low cerebral blood flow are likely to have hypertension, heart disease, diabetes mellitus, and/or hyperlipidemia (Meyer et al., 1984). The concentration of oxygen in the surrounding environment is sensed by the chemoreceptors in the neck and brain. The sympathetic nervous system mediates body’s response to acute hypoxia by increasing breathing and heart rates. At the cellular level, hypoxia is sensed by the hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) which activate genes to increase oxygen transport and anaerobic respiration. As mitochondria are the main consumers of oxygen in the cell, HIF pathways and mitochondria cross talk during hypoxic conditions (X. Huang et al., 2023). Although hypoxia is associated with age-related diseases such as cancer and obstructive sleep apnea (E. Yeo, 2019), moderate and controlled hypoxia has been reported to have beneficial impact on the aging neurological and cardiovascular systems (Burtscher et al., 2021; Raberin et al., 2023). Fatigue is one of the most common symptoms experienced by the elderly, with or without chronic disease. As fatigue is a hallmark symptom of mitochondrial diseases, the association between fatigue and mitochondria dysfunction was investigated and reviewed (Filler et al., 2014). Furthermore, a recent study revealed mitochondria dysfunction in the skeletal muscle of patients with long COVID presenting with post-exertional malaise (Appelman et al., 2024). The five common comorbidities of chronic fatigue syndrome are depression, anxiety disorder, insomnia, Crohn’s disease, and ulcerative colitis (Leong et al., 2022). Cardiomyocytes stop proliferating soon after birth and the heart grows through increase in the size of cardiomyocytes throughout adolescence. During adulthood, cardiac stress from e.g., exercise or hypertension causes loss of some cardiomyocytes, which hardly regenerate. The pathologic cardiac stress accumulates over time, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, cardiomyocyte death, inflammation, fibrosis, and functional decline of the heart later in life (Mendoza & Karch, 2022). A study found that each 15 beats per minute increase in the resting heart rate increases the risk of cardiovascular disease mortality by a factor of 1.2 in healthy men and 1.3 in healthy women (Cooney et al., 2010). Elevated heart rate also comes before hypertension, obesity, and diabetes (Palatini, 2011). The right ventricle pumps blood to the lung and the left ventricle to the rest of the body. If the blood pressure or blood volume to the ventricle increase during growth, pregnancy, or exercise, the muscles in the ventricular walls grow to overcome the increased workload from the vascular system. If the workload persists in, e.g., systemic hypertension and there is no sufficient proliferation of the vasculature in the hypertrophic ventricle, cardiomyocyte death, inflammation, and fibrosis can occur, leading to malignant arrhythmia and heart failure. Pathological left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), more common than right ventricular hypertrophy, results from maladaptive responses of the left ventricle to blood pressure overload. Mitochondria occupy about one third of the cardiomyocyte volume to supply 90% of the cardiomyocyte ATP. Alterations in mitochondrial morphology, biogenesis, dynamics, and bioenergetics during cardiac hypertrophy in cardiac hypertrophy were extensively studied and reviewed (D. Yang et al., 2022). The prevalence of LVH was 9% and individuals with LVH were older and likely to have hypertension, diabetes, or cardiovascular disease (Taki et al., 2023). Epinephrine prepares one for either a fight or flight through stimulating the sympathetic nervous system, causing the heart to pump faster and harder; making one to breathe deeper and faster; raising one’s blood sugar; diverting blood flow toward muscles and away from the skin; and dilating one’s eye pupils. Epinephrine secretion at rest and under stress was found to be lower in older men than in younger men (Esler et al., 1995). Mitochondrial DNA deletion and mitochondria dysfunction were shown to accumulate with age in the adrenal medulla and cortex; and the mitochondrial dysfunction-induced adrenal degeneration could explain the decline in adrenal hormonal and steroidal secretion during aging (Neuhaus et al., 2016). Low levels of epinephrine can result in depression, headache, and hypoglycemia. It was found that plasma urea increases with age due to a more decrease in urea clearance than in urea production in older subjects (Musch et al., 2006). The first two steps of urea cycle take place in the mitochondria of liver cells. It was found that increased intracellular urea in human hair follicle derived-mesenchymal stem cells and mouse skin and heart tissues severely impairs mitochondrial function and exacerbates aging (Choudhury et al., 2022). Hypertension and schizophrenia or bipolar affective disorder are the physical and mental conditions most strongly associated with chronic kidney disease (MacRae et al., 2021). Total lean body mass (exclusive of bone) and total skeletal muscle mass were found to decline linearly with age (Melton et al., 2000). Aged skeletal muscles exhibit increased mutations of mitochondrial DNA, decreased activity of some mitochondrial enzymes, reduced maximal respiration capacity, and reduced total mitochondrial content with increased morphological changes (Peterson et al., 2012). Age-related loss of muscle mass and strength is highly prevalent in patients with cardiovascular disease, dementia, diabetes, and respiratory disease (Pacifico et al., 2020). The risk of peripheral edema increases with age, with a prevalence of ~20% among adults over 50 years old (Besharat et al., 2021). Edema is a common symptom of heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, or cirrhosis, the latter of which is characterized by such mitochondria dysfunction as increased mitochondrial ROS production; increased mitochondrial calcium concentration; and reduced mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (Middleton & Vergis, 2021). Diabetes, heart failure, and reduced mobility are the common comorbidities of chronic edema in elderly patients (Moffatt et al., 2019). The prevalence of varicose veins increases with age due to the aging venous system (Beebe-Dimmer et al., 2005). Both the total mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and proportion of no-deletion mtDNA were found to be lower in the varicose vein tissue samples than non-varicose vein tissue samples from patients with varicose veins (Smetanina et al., 2022). The presence of varicose veins is associated with an increased risk of developing deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and peripheral artery disease (S. Chang et al., 2018). Chapter 5 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Cellular Senescence Cellular senescence is a state of irreversible cell cycle arrest. Although senescent cells are no longer capable of division, they remain metabolically active and exert paracrine effects on their microenvironment through the release of senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) factors. These factors include inflammatory cytokines, immune modulators, growth factors, and proteases, which can influence neighboring cells. Transient SASP has been implicated in processes such as embryonic development, tissue repair, and wound healing (W. Huang et al., 2022). However, prolonged senescence—induced by telomere shortening, oxidative stress, and DNA damage caused by radiation or genotoxic agents—ultimately leads to chronic inflammation and tissue dysfunction. Traditional Chinese medicine treatments such as Xuèfǔzhúyūtāng, Dānshēn, Dúhuójìshēngtāng, Shūjīnghuóxuètāng, Chēqiánzǐ, Yùjīn, Tiānmágōuténgyǐn, Zhūlíngtāng, acupuncture, Zhìgāncǎotāng, Yìqìcōngmíngtāng, Jìshēngshènqìwán, and Shíhú are frequently used to address aging phenotypes linked to cellular senescence. Notably, acupuncture has demonstrated efficacy in this context, as evidenced by a study showing that electroacupuncture prevents stress-induced premature senescence in nucleus pulposus cells of rabbits with degenerative intervertebral discs (M. Wang et al., 2025). 5.1 Kyphosis Kyphosis is an excessive outward curving of the thoracic spine resulting in a bowing or rounding of the upper back. After the age of 40 years, the degree of kyphosis in ~30% of adults increases with age at a rate of about 0.5 degree per year and the rate of increase is higher in females than in males (Katzman et al., 2010). In aging, some of the cell types in the bone and intervertebral disc microenvironment become senescent, causing bone loss and disc degeneration (X. He et al., 2023; Silwal et al., 2023). Kyphosis would result if aggregated senescent cells take a toll on the thoracic spine. Kyphosis is associated with osteoporotic vertebral fracture and decline in lung function (Lorbergs et al., 2017; Van Der Jagt-Willems et al., 2015). Chen, Qu, et al., 2022). 5.2 Osteoporosis Osteoporosis is characterized by a decreased bone density, rendering the bone weak and fragile. The bone is a living tissue; old and micro-damaged bones are dissolved and new bones are created in the place of the old ones in a process called bone remodeling. In aging, the number and activity of the bone formation cells decline while the activity of the bone resorption cells remain, leading to osteoporosis. In the bone microenvironment of aging mice, the senescent cells and their SASP that contribute to the imbalanced bone homeostasis were identified (Farr et al., 2016). The prevalence of osteoporosis in adults aged 50 years and older was found to be 9%; females were more likely to have osteoporosis; and arthrosis and arthritis were the top two comorbidities of age-related osteoporosis (Puth et al., 2018). The middle (i.e. muscular) layer of the arterial walls that determines the biomechanical property of the arteries comprises collagen, elastin, and vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs). In aging, the elastic fibers can fracture due to material fatigue, reducing vascular elasticity. Furthermore, senescent VSMCs found in aged vessels are replaced by fibrotic scars, augmenting age-related arterial stiffening (Schellinger et al., 2019). Arterial stiffening was found to be more severe in men than in premenopausal women; more severe in postmenopausal women than in men; and associated with chronic kidney disease and diabetes (Y. Lu et al., 2020). Atherosclerosis, a type of arteriosclerosis, is caused by a buildup of plaque made of fatty substances on the inner arterial walls, hardening and narrowing the arteries. Senescent vascular endothelial cells, senescent VSMCs, and senescent macrophages are involved in the formation and development of atherosclerosis (C. Wu et al., 2020). Calcium ions (Ca2+), the most versatile cellular messenger in signal transduction, regulate cellular activities through organized cytosolic Ca2+ concentration, kinetics, and spatial localization in response to extrinsic and intrinsic stimuli in every cell of the body. Disrupted cellular Ca2+ signaling and/or Ca2+ homeostasis can have pathological outcomes. A rise in intracellular Ca2+ accompanies cellular senescence (Martin & Bernard, 2018). Studies have elucidated the role of cellular senescent in vascular calcification (Mackenzie & MacRae, 2011; Mas-Bargues et al., 2022) and valvular calcification (Molnár et al., 2022). The abdominal aorta starts to calcify at age of 40 years and then the ascending thoracic aorta calcifies later in life; BMI and hypertension are among the risk factors of vascular calcification (Jadidi et al., 2021). The macroscopic changes of the kidney with age are characterized by a decrease in the volume of renal parenchyma and scarring of the renal surface, while the age-related microscopic kidney changes include global glomerulosclerosis, focal tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis. The structural changes result in functional decline of the kidney. For example, 5-10% decrease in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) per decade after age 35 years was reported (Glassock & Rule, 2012). The declining renal function also correlates with increase in the senescent load of the renal tubular endothelial cells and glomerular podocytes (Rex et al., 2023). Hypertension, obesity, ischemic heart disease, and diabetes were found to be commonly comorbid with decreased renal function (Hirst et al., 2021). Angiotensin II, produced in vascular tissues, is the major bioactive product of the RAAS, and was demonstrated to promote vascular inflammation by inducing premature senescence of vascular smooth muscle cells in vascular aging (Kunieda et al., 2006). Angiotensin II levels were found to correlate with degree of depression in patients with coronary artery disease (W. Han et al., 2020). The roles of accumulated senescent retinal ganglion cells in the development of glaucoma were reviewed (Y. Zhang, Huang, et al., 2024). Overweight/obesity, migraine, asthma, and smoking increase the risk of conversion from ocular hypertension to open-angle glaucoma, the most common clinical subtype of glaucoma (Garcia-Villanueva et al., 2022). Chapter 6 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Deregulated Nutrient-sensing The body relies on energy and essential materials from food to sustain vital physiological processes, including respiration, cognition, waste elimination, tissue growth, cellular repair, and energy storage. A sophisticated network of biochemical pathways has evolved to monitor and respond to fluctuations in nutrient levels—such as glucose, amino acids, and fatty acids—orchestrating shifts between cellular recycling/repair during nutrient scarcity and synthesis/growth during periods of abundance. However, prolonged nutrient overload, driven by factors like excessive sugar consumption, high-fat diets, sedentary behavior, or circadian rhythm disruption, suppresses cellular repair mechanisms and heightens oxidative stress (a consequence of metabolic byproducts). This imbalance accelerates cellular damage and contributes to organismal aging. Frequently prescribed constituents in GMP herbal prescriptions for aging symptoms associated with deregulated nutrient-sensing pathways include: Dānshēn, Shānzhā, Yuǎnzhì, Bǔyánghuánwǔtāng, Shíchāngpú, Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn, Fángfēngtōngshèngsǎn, Héshǒuwū, Liùwèidìhuángwán, Shūjīnghuóxuètāng, Juémíngzǐ, and Suānzǎoréntāng. Single-herb GMP prescriptions targeting deregulated nutrient-sensing aging traits commonly include: Dàhuáng, Chìsháo, Gāncǎo, Dìhuáng, Huángqí, Huánglián, Báizhú, Fúlíng, Huángqín, Zhǐshí, Xuánshēn, Héshǒuwū, Fùzǐ, Dāngguī, Dānshēn, Dǎngshēn, and Báisháo. 6.1 Obesity Obesity is a condition where fats in the body accumulate to the extent that one’s health is compromised. A measure to quantify obesity is when one’s body mass index (BMI) exceeds 30 kg/m2. A multi-cohort epidemiological study found that obesity better predicts aging hallmark related diseases than other risk factors including education, dietary factors, smoking, physical activity, alcohol consumption, and depression, and that obesity most likely cooccurs with diseases related to deregulated nutrient sensing (Kivimäki et al., 2024). It was found that three out of every four patients in the United States were overweight with a BMI greater than 25 kg/m2 and that increasing BMI was associated with diabetes, prediabetes, and hypertension (Pantalone et al., 2017). Unintentional weight loss is encountered in about 8% of adult outpatients and 27% of frail people aged 65 years and over and is associated with an increased mortality (Alibhai et al., 2005). The causes of unintentional weight loss include malignancy, depression, nonmalignant gastrointestinal disease, and endocrine disorder. However, about a quarter of the elderly with unintentional weight loss have no obvious medical causes. Among the cancers associated with weight loss, the top ten cancer were found to be prostate, colorectal, lung, gastroesophageal, pancreatic, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, ovarian, multiple myeloma, renal tract, and biliary tree (B. D. Nicholson et al., 2018). In the elderly, nonmalignant diseases are more common than malignant diseases to cause weight loss. Infection, medication, and polypharmacy that interrupt taste or cause nausea can also result in unintentional weight loss in the elderly. Triglycerides are the most common type of fat in the body, coming from foods, such as butter and oils, or from extra calories. Consistent high levels of triglycerides in the blood mix with other fatty substances in the blood, such as cholesterol, sticking to the walls of the arteries to cause atherosclerosis. Too much fat can also build up in the liver and pancreas, causing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and inflammation of the pancreas (Pedersen et al., 2016; Tomizawa et al., 2014). A fifth of the global female adult population and more than a third of the global male population had hypertriglyceridemia (Grupo de Investigación del Estudio SIMETAP, 2020). Low serum albumin, i.e., hypoalbuminemia, can manifest fluid-induced swelling of the legs, buildup of fluid in the abdomen, and collection of fluid in hollow organs. Hypoalbuminemia can be due to insufficient production of albumin by the liver as in liver failure; excessive loss of albumin in the urine as in nephrotic syndrome; leakage/malabsorption of proteins from the gastrointestinal tract as in ulcerative colitis; or decreased intake of proteins in malnutrition as in thin and frail elders. Lower serum albumin was also noted in the acute phases of psychiatric inpatients with mania or major depression (T. Huang, 2002). HGH promotes growth of the body—especially the cartilages and bones of the adolescents in puberty—through stimulated synthesis of proteins and increased breakdown of fat to provide the energy necessary for tissue growth. HGH continues to help maintain tissues and organs in adulthood and throughout life. Upon receipt of a nerve impulse, glutamate is released from the vesicles in the axon terminal into synaptic cleft for the binding by glutamate receptors in the postsynaptic neurons. Part of the glutamate in the synapse is taken up by the neighboring astrocyte where glutamate is converted into glutamine. Glutamine in the astrocyte is shuttled back to the neuron. The glutamine entering the neuron is converted to glutamate and repackaged in the presynaptic vesicles, completing the glutamate-glutamine cycle. Glutamate levels were found to decrease in normal aged adults and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients (D. Huang et al., 2017; Roalf et al., 2020). Lower levels of prefrontal glutamate were shown to contribute to working memory deficits and decision-making impairment in older adulthood (Rmus et al., 2023). Total body potassium was found to decrease from 41 years onward in men and 60 years onward in women as they age (Flynn et al., 1989). Chronic diarrhea and diuretic use are the two common causes of hypokalemia (Viera & Wouk, 2015). Vegetables, fruits, milk, yogurt, and nuts are rich sources of potassium. Note that excessive intake of licorice decreases blood potassium levels (Mumoli & Cei, 2008). Conditions that are associated with and/or exacerbated by chronic magnesium deficiency include hypertension, diabetes, osteoporosis, and migraines (Ismail et al., 2018). Diets rich in magnesium include green leafy vegetables, legumes, nuts, seeds, whole grains, yogurt, banana, salmon, and milk. Plasma noradrenaline concentration increases with age due principally to reduced noradrenaline clearance from the circulation (Esler et al., 1981). Drugs modulating the noradrenergic system, parts of the body that produce or are affected by noradrenaline, have been shown to be effective in the treatment of eating disorders including binge eating disorder and bulimia nervosa (Pruccoli et al., 2021). Abnormalities in the noradrenergic system are associated with anxiety spectrum disorders such as panic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and phobias (Sullivan et al., 1999). Aberrance in the functional connectivity network of the noradrenergic neurons was also present in patients with comorbid migraine and chronic insomnia (C. Wang et al., 2024). Chapter 7 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Stem Cell Exhaustion Many tissues in the human body, such as bone marrow, the brain, skin, the intestine, cornea, muscle, testes/ovaries, and connective tissues (e.g., adipose tissue and synovium), harbor adult stem cells. These multipotent cells possess the capacity to self-renew and differentiate into specialized cell types essential for tissue maintenance and repair. However, as organisms age, the number and functional capacity of adult stem cells decline. This decline is driven by multiple factors, including DNA damage, telomere shortening, epigenetic drift, mitochondrial dysfunction, as well as alterations within the stem cell niche. These changes collectively impair regenerative abilities and contribute to age-related degeneration. In traditional Chinese medicine, certain components of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP)-certified herbal prescriptions are frequently employed to address aging-related phenotypes associated with stem cell exhaustion. These include: Dānshēn, Ròucōngróng, Yínyánghuò, Bājǐtiān, Jiāwèixiāoyáosǎn, Zhìgāncǎotāng, Xiānhècǎo, Sǎnzhǒngkuìjiāntāng, Xuánshēn, Guīpítāng, Hànliáncǎo, Chìsháo, Xiàkūcǎo, Tùsīzǐ, Xuèfǔzhúyūtāng, and Fùfāngdānshēnpiàn. 7.1 Alopecia Alopecia, or hair loss, increases with age. In men, male pattern baldness is characterized by hair loss in the frontotemporal and vertex regions of the scalp, starting with a receding hairline above both temples, while in women female pattern hair loss presents a diffuse thinning of the hair across the entire scalp, starting at the hair division line. Hair starts growing at the bottom of a hair follicle at a speed of 1-1.5 cm per month. The lifespan of hair is up to seven years and new hair grows in the follicle where the old one falls away. In aged mice, hair follicle stem cells were found to escape from their niche, contributing to hair follicle miniaturization and permanent hair loss (C. Zhang et al., 2021). The percentage of people over age 65 years with hair loss was estimated at 53% in men and 37% in women (Villani et al., 2022). Male pattern baldness was reviewed to be associated with endocrine disease such as hyperandrogenemia, cancer such as prostate cancer, metabolic disease such as hypertriglyceridemia, and cardiovascular disease such as heart disease (S. Chen et al., 2022). Female pattern hair loss was found to be associated with age, menopause, and hypertension (Özkoca et al., 2022). IHD manifests chest pain or discomfort which may radiate to other parts of the upper body including the left shoulder, arm, back, neck, jaw, or stomach. Poor blood supply to the heart in IHD is due mainly to narrowed coronary arteries by accumulation of atherosclerotic plaques on the inner arterial walls. Mesenchymal stem cells were shown to attenuate atherosclerosis progression through immunosuppression in mice (J. Li et al., 2019) and represent a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (Gorabi et al., 2019). The global prevalence of IHD was projected to double between 2021 and 2050, reaching 5% by 2050 (H. Shi et al., 2025). IHD patients with respiratory and musculoskeletal comorbidities were found to have the highest risk of mortality (Crowe et al., 2020). Xu et al., 2012). 7.3 Myocardial infarction Myocardial infarction (MI), also known as heart attack, refers to tissue death of part of the heart muscle due to lack of oxygen supply to the affected heart muscle. The cutting off of blood supply in acute MI is mostly caused by a ruptured atherosclerotic plague that forms a clot to clog the affected coronary artery. Treatment of a heart attack by pharmaceutically or surgically restoring blood supply to the affected heart muscle is crucial before more heart muscle cells die. Because heart muscle has limited regenerative capability, transplantation of autologous bone marrow stem cells after MI has attracted attention to restore heart function (W. Yan et al., 2024). The global prevalence of MI in adults aged 60 years and older was estimated at 9.5%, compared with 3.8% in adults aged 59 years and younger (Salari et al., 2023). The common non-cardiovascular comorbidities of MI were found to be chronic renal disease and anemia (Teng et al., 2020). In aging, the number of skeletal/stem progenitor cells (SSPCs), e.g., hematopoietic stem cells and mesenchymal stem cells, reduces; some of the SSPCs become senescent; and the microenvironment of the SSPCs is chronically inflamed. Aged SSPCs exhibit deteriorated regenerative potential, leading ultimately to age-associated bone fractures and lack of repair (Mancinelli & Intini, 2023). Dementia and diabetes were found to have a significantly negative impact on patients with surgically treated fragility hip fractures (S. H. Yoon et al., 2021). Serum PTH was found to increase with age regardless of vitamin D levels in normocalcemic individuals without renal dysfunction (Cavalcante et al., 2023). Note that although continual exposure to high levels of PTH causes bone resorption, intermittent exposure to controlled dose of PTH stimulates bone forming cells more than bone resorbing cells (Ponnapakkam et al., 2013). Artificially made PTH is therefore used for the treatment of osteoporosis. It was found that aging causes a decrease in the expression of PTH and PTH receptors in the dental pulp stem cells from human premolars, impairing the osteogenic differentiation ability of the dental pulp stem cells (Bhandi et al., 2021). Primary hyperparathyroidism was found to be associated with diabetes, renal stones, and osteoporosis, independent of serum vitamin D concentration (Soto-Pedre et al., 2023). Serum prolactin was found to rise slightly with increasing age in men and to fall slightly in women until age 80, when it rises slightly (Sawin et al., 1989). Chapter 8 GMP Herbal Medicine for Aging due to Chronic Inflammation, Altered Intercellular Communication, and Dysbiosis Chronic inflammation is defined by the prolonged presence of pro-inflammatory cytokines and persistent activation of the innate immune system in the absence of active injury or infection. It can arise from various factors, including unresolved pathogen infections, repeated exposure to antigens or toxins, autoimmune disorders, immunosenescence, obesity and physical inactivity, tobacco and alcohol use, chronic physiological or psychological stress, disrupted sleep and circadian rhythms, and gut microbiome dysbiosis. In traditional Chinese medicine, herbal prescriptions frequently used to address aging-related conditions linked to chronic inflammation include: Dānshēn, Xuèfǔzhúyūtāng, Niúxī, Fùzǐ, Yùjīn, Shūjīnghuóxuètāng, Dàhuáng, Shēngmàiyǐn, Bǔzhōngyìqìtāng, Zhūlíngtāng, Jìshēngshènqìwán, Guīpítāng, Huǒmárén, Héshǒuwū, Dùzhòng, Shānzhā, Tiānmágōuténgyǐn, Gānlùyǐn, Língguìshùgāntāng, Dāngguīniāntòngtāng, and Sānqī. Acupuncture, another modality commonly co-prescribed for chronic inflammation, exerts anti-inflammatory effects through neuro-immune regulatory mechanisms, as reviewed by N. Li et al. (2021). 8.1 Dyskinesia Dyskinesia is involuntary, excessive movements, such as tremors and tics, of one or multiple muscles of the body including the face, limbs, and trunk. One of the first-line treatments for Parkinson’s disease is levodopa, whose side effects include dyskinesia. Neuroinflammation was reviewed to contribute to levodopa-induced dyskinesia in Parkinsonian patients receiving levodopa therapy (Cardinale et al., 2024). Furthermore, it was found that an antibiotic that decontaminates the intestine improves levodopa-induced dyskinesia in Parkinsonian patients (Baizabal-Carvallo et al., 2021). The global prevalence of first- and second-generation antipsychotic-induced tardive dyskinesia was estimated to be 30% and 21%, respectively (Carbon et al., 2017). Lǐzhōngtāng was introduced for subacute delirium in Section 2.1. 8.2 Headache The prevalence of headache decreases with increasing age; however, a major neurological complaint in the elderly is headache. Older people often experience tension headache or migraine; the former presents squeezing pain around the head and the latter manifests throbbing pain on one side of the head. Older people also suffer from headaches secondary to an underlying condition such as cervical spine disease, hypertension, and medication overuse. Migraines are believed to be caused by inflammatory responses to the activation and sensitization of the neurons of the trigeminovascular system (Spekker et al., 2021). Tension headaches are caused by contraction of the muscles of the scalp and neck, and are predominantly treated by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. A study found an association between depression and medication overuse headache and between obstructive sleep apnea and hypertension-induced headache in patients over 50 years of age (Togha et al., 2022). The risk of vertigo was also found to be associated with the abundance of specific gut microbiota taxa in humans with the taxa-specific association being mediated through depression or obesity (Q. It was shown that high-fructose or high-fat feeds cause changes in intestinal microbiota to induce chronic intestinal inflammation and constipation in mice (R. Tan et al., 2021). Moreover, higher inflammatory potential of the diet was found to increase the risk of constipation in adults (W. F. Lu et al., 2025). Neurological diseases, including Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis, and cardiovascular diseases, including angina and myocardial infarction, were found to be linked to chronic constipation in community residents (Choung et al., 2015). Globally, one third of people aged 30 to 79 years had hypertension (NCD Risk Factor Collaboration, 2021); however, 70% American adults over 65 years of age were hypertensive (Mozaffarian et al., 2015). Over 90% of hypertensive cases have no known direct causes; they are called idiopathic hypertension, essential hypertension, or primary hypertension. Recent studies have observed increased systemic inflammation to precede blood pressure elevation; inflammatory infiltration to the renal interstitium and vascular wall culminate the elevated blood pressure (Solak et al., 2016); and anti-inflammatory drugs were suggested to treat hypertension (Dinh et al., 2014). Obesity and dyslipidemia are common in hypertensive patients (Noh et al., 2016). Creatinine is filtered out from the blood by the kidney into urine. Serum creatinine levels are used to monitor kidney function and also muscle mass. Serum creatinine levels were found to significantly decrease with age in healthy men due to skeletal muscle mass decline (Yim et al., 2023). Chronic systemic and/or local inflammation tip protein metabolism toward hyper-catabolism and interfere with the myogenic program, contributing to skeletal mass wasting (Costamagna et al., 2015). Muscle wasting is associated with cancer and renal failure. Persistent low-grade inflammation plays key roles in the pathogenesis and complications of chronic kidney disease (CKD); and a bidirectional relationship between gut microbiota dysbiosis and CKD pathogenesis and progression has also been established (Mihai et al., 2018). CKD affects more than 10% of the general population globally and is associated with diabetes and hypertension (Kovesdy, 2022). The prevalence of angina is higher in men than in women and increases with age (N. F. Murphy et al., 2006). Circulating levels of inflammatory markers were found to be significantly increased in patients with angina (Yip et al., 2005). Without oxygen, the brain cells in the affected region of the brain will die. Strokes are the leading cause of serious long-term disability. The prevalence of stroke increases with age, reaching ~7% in the elderly (Rajati et al., 2023). The pathobiology and outcomes of a stroke are determined by the local and systemic inflammatory response to the hypoperfused vessels and ischemic brain parenchyma; and gut microbiota and brain ischemia interact with each other through the intestinal immune system (Anrather & Iadecola, 2016). Older stroke patients comorbid with diabetes or depression were found to be associated with difficulty in activity of daily living (Ruksakulpiwat et al., 2023). The repetitive mechanical stress from cardiac cycle wears and tears the mitral valve over time; the prevalence of valvular heart disease (VHD) increases with age: from ~1% in 18–44 year olds to 13% in the 75 years and older (Nkomo et al., 2006). Mitral regurgitation, one of the most common VHDs, is most likely caused by mitral valve prolapse (MVP) in developed countries; and a set of inflammatory markers was identified in the blood sample of patients with MVP (Yalim & Ersoy, 2021). In developing world, the mitral valve can also be damaged by repeated streptococcal throat infection, resulting in rheumatic heart disease (RHD). The microbiota in the gut, oral cavity, and mitral valve were found to alter in RHD patients compared with controls (X. Shi et al., 2021). MVP appears to correlate with psychiatric disorders such as anxiety disorders and panic disorder (Gonzalez et al., 2002). Aneurysms can occur in any blood vessel including the thoracic aorta, abdominal aorta, and internal carotid artery. If the blood pressure on the bulging wall exceeds the wall strength, the aneurysm can burst, leading to life-threatening internal hemorrhage. Recruitment and infiltration of inflammatory effectors to aneurysmal walls are prominent feature of aortic aneurysms (Z. Yuan et al., 2021) and cerebral aneurysms (Hudson et al., 2013), demonstrating the critical roles of inflammation in the formation, progression and rupture of aneurysms. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, smoking, and coronary artery disease (Müller et al., 2019). Cholesterol functions as a precursor for steroid hormones, sex hormones, vitamin D and bile acids and as a building block of cell membranes. Cholesterol metabolism is maintained by a highly coordinated actions between cholesterol ingestion, synthesis, absorption, and excretion. Nevertheless, total plasma cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol were found to curvilinearly (linearly) increase with age in men (women) and HDL-cholesterol raise slightly over time in both sexes (Heiss et al., 1980). Note that LDL-cholesterol contributes to plaque formation in the arteries while HDL-cholesterol gets removed by the liver. Gut microbiota was reviewed to influence cholesterol metabolism by 1) changing bile acid reabsorption; 2) producing short-chain-fatty-acids, which inhibit hepatic cholesterol synthesis; 3) regulating the expression of cholesterol metabolism genes; 4) converting cholesterol into non-absorbable sterol; and 5) inhibiting production of endotoxin which increases hepatic cholesterol synthesis (C. Deng et al., 2023). Hypertensive or diabetic patients with severe hypercholesterolemia have a higher risk of mortality (Miles et al., 2023). The percentage of adults with arthritis increases with age, from ~4% in adults aged 18–34 years to 54% in adults aged 75 years and older (Elgaddal et al., 2024). Among the many types of arthritis, the most common among the elderly is osteoarthritis (OA), which starts with wearing and tearing of the cartilage that cushions the opposing bones, leading to erosion of the affected bones. OA often occurs in weight-bearing bones such as the back, hip, and knee. About half of the older patients with arthritis also have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, dementia, stroke, heart disease, diabetes, or cancer (Fallon et al., 2023). The level of serum ferritin, which correlates with total iron storage in the body, was found to rise with age (Casale et al., 1981). Glycation due to hyperglycemia can damage ferritin, resulting in leakage of free iron. Excessive free iron generates highly reactive ROS via the Fenton reaction, causing oxidative damage to biomolecules. Ferritin levels were indeed found to be significantly higher in geriatric patients with subclinical inflammatory state (Cankurtaran et al., 2012). Diabetes, arrhythmias, and liver cirrhosis are associated with iron overload (Yassine et al., 2023).
